headline.main: FROM-PARIS.; Probabilities of a General European WarThe Turn of Events in Poland CatholicFlings at the Emperor Napolean Austriaand Italy Another French Minister, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: In my opinion the probabilities of a general war are greatly increased by the events of Warsaw. They very much perplex the calculations of the Emperor NAPOLEON, and will very likely reduce him to give up all hopes of the Russian alliance, (with which he has long been coqueting,) and no declare himself frankly and openly in favor of "nationalities" all over Europe.

docs.snippet: There seems now to be no longer any necessity for fearing for the safety of Washington. From information furnished to us from apparently authentic sources, we have no doubt that the Sixth, Seventh, Twelfth and Seventy-first New York Regiments are now...
docs.lead_paragraph: There seems now to be no longer any necessity for fearing for the safety of Washington. From information furnished to us from apparently authentic sources, we have no doubt that the Sixth, Seventh, Twelfth and Seventy-first New York Regiments are now there, and prepared, with the troops from other States which have also reached there, to oppose successfully any demonstration which the Secessionists may see fit to make against the place.

docs.snippet: Telegraphic communication with Washington is still an impossibility, but we receive gratifying assurances through other channels that the Capital may now be considered safe against the assault of any force which is likely to be brought against it....
docs.lead_paragraph: Telegraphic communication with Washington is still an impossibility, but we receive gratifying assurances through other channels that the Capital may now be considered safe against the assault of any force which is likely to be brought against it. The number of troops now there must be at least ten thousand, and will probably be twenty thousand within twenty-four hours.

docs.snippet: During the first quarter of the year 1861, ending on the 1st inst., the City Inspector has reported 5,167 deaths in New-York. The weekly average has been, in January, 397; in February, 392; in March, 403. For the whole 13 weeks, there has been an...
docs.lead_paragraph: During the first quarter of the year 1861, ending on the 1st inst., the City Inspector has reported 5,167 deaths in New-York. The weekly average has been, in January, 397; in February, 392; in March, 403. For the whole 13 weeks, there has been an average of 567 deaths each day. The mortality for the quarter shows a decrease of 1,038, or 16.7 per cent as compared with the first quarter of the year 1860.
